intro: Otopappus brevipes var. glabratus, commonly known as the smoothleaf desert parsley, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its basal leaves are smooth and lance-shaped, while the stems are often hairy. The fruit is a dry, two-lobed schizocarp, typical of the carrot family.
